solution-article.title: RAM
solution-article.description:
The 840 G1, 840 G2, Zbook15 G1, Zbook15 G2, and 8570w all use the same RAM.

 

DDR3L 1600MHz PC3L-12800 SODIMM RAM

These are available from Amazon with a cost of approximately $40 for the 4GB and $80 for the 8GB. 

 

All of the above models have 1 slot free for RAM except the Zbook15 G2 which has 3 slots free.

solution-article.title: Email class list using BlackBoard or Outlook.
solution-article.description: my.msoe offers a more reliably correct roster than Black Board due to the connection between my.msoe and Jenzabar.  Faculty and advisors have grown accustomed to using this because of this reason.  This feature can still be utilized in my.msoe.  Copy and paste the class roster from the to field in your my.msoe email and paste it into BlackBoard or Outlook and email while Jenzabar continues to work on a solution.

solution-article.title: Network Connects but no Internet
solution-article.description:
1. Check for 3rd party VPN or firewall. Disable if necessary.
  2. Reset TCP/IP stack and winsock catalog
    1. Open command prompt as administrator
    2. netsh int ip reset
    3. netsh winsock reset
    4. Restart computer
  3. Refresh IP configuration
    1. Open command prompt
    2. ipconfig /release
    3. ipconfig /renew
  4. Reinstall network drivers from USB drive


- Paul Page
solution-article.desc-un-html:
Check for 3rd party VPN or firewall. Disable if necessary. Reset TCP/IP stack and winsock catalog
Open command prompt as administrator netsh int ip reset netsh winsock reset Restart computer
Refresh IP configuration
Open command prompt ipconfig /release ipconfig /renew
Reinstall network drivers from USB drive
- Paul Page

solution-article.title: Personal laptop can't connect to MSOE or MSOE-LIB
solution-article.description:
If the computer is having issue connecting a personal laptop to the MSOE SSID or any radius authentication signal, but CAN connect to an open network like Guest, here are the steps that should resolve the issue:

1. In the Networking and Sharing Center, select “Set up a new connection or network” and select to “Manually connect to a wireless network”.

2. Use the following:

Network Name: MSOE [or whatever network you're trying to connect to]

Security Type: WPA2-Enterprise

Encryption Type: AES

Security Key: [blank]

3. Once this profile is added, select "Change Connection Settings". Click on the Security tab.

4. Under "Choose a network authentication method", keep it on "Microsoft: Protect EAP (PEAP)" but click the "Settings" button.

5. Under "Select Authentication Method", keep the MSCHAPv2 option but click on "Configure".

6. De-select the option that states "Automatically use my Windows logon name and password".

7. Select OK three times and try to connect. Should now ask for a username and password.
solution-article.desc-un-html:
If the computer is having issue connecting a personal laptop to the MSOE SSID or any radius authentication signal, but CAN connect to an open network like Guest, here are the steps that should resolve the issue:
1. In the Networking and Sharing Center, select “Set up a new connection or network” and select to “Manually connect to a wireless network”.
2. Use the following:
Network Name: MSOE [or whatever network you're trying to connect to]
Security Type: WPA2-Enterprise
Encryption Type: AES
Security Key: [blank]
3. Once this profile is added, select "Change Connection Settings". Click on the Security tab.
4. Under "Choose a network authentication method", keep it on "Microsoft: Protect EAP (PEAP)" but click the "Settings" button.
5. Under "Select Authentication Method", keep the MSCHAPv2 option but click on "Configure".
6. De-select the option that states "Automatically use my Windows logon name and password".
7. Select OK three times and try to connect. Should now ask for a username and password.

solution-article.title: Backing Up Your Data
solution-article.description:
Backing Up Your Data

Consistently backing up your data is the best way to prevent substantial data loss. This guide will explain your options for backing up your data, and will walk you through the steps to back up your data. There are two main options for data backup available to you, physical and virtual, below we will explain these options to you.

Physical Storage: Jump Drives, Flash Drives, SD cards, External Hard Drives, CDs, DVDs, Magnetic Tape, Floppy Disks

Physical storage is storage which you purchase or acquire (like a flash/jump drive) and use to store and back up your data manually. In the past several years, these options have dropped significantly in price, and have become very affordable for the common user. Most of these options require little technical knowledge and offer a simple "drag and drop" interface. Below are some of the Pros and Cons of this type of data back up, along with a general step by step instructional guide to using the most common type, flash drives.

                Pros:                                                                                Cons:

 · Low Price                                                                     · Venerable to Hardware Failure

 · Mobile                                                                          · Not Expandable

 · Available without the Internet                                      · Vulnerable to malicious software

 · You control your data                                                   · Stealable/Losable

 · More security options                                            

Using Physical Storage: Flash Drives

A Flash Drive, sometimes called a JumpDrive is a type of removable physical storage that allows files to be stored as well as transferred from one device to another. You have probably used one of these at some point of your life, so the interface and function is likely familiar for you, below, we will detail how to use a flash drive to back up your files.

What do I need?: a Flash Drive (Wondering how big? See "How Much Storage do I Need?") and a Free USB port.

Step 1: Connect your drive. Connect your USB drive by placing it in one of the free USB ports on your computer. 

Step 2: Find your drive. First, go to your start menu, then type "file explorer" (in legacy [Devices running Windows 7 and earlier], select "My Documents")

Step 3: Click "This PC", and you should see a screen that looks like this:

Step 4: Double click your "removable disk" (On some devices, it may also be called a USB Storage Device, or the brand name, [Ex. a Sandisk device may be called SANDISK]) Removable disk is the nick name your device gives the flash drive. Your screen should look like this. If you already have put files and/or folders in, they will show up here.

Step 5: Click the small arrow, which will cause a menu to expand. It will look like this:

Step 6: Go to whatever folder you have your file(s) in, and find the document(s) you are looking for, then follow the instructions on the image below:

Step 7: Repeat as Necessary. 

Virtual Storage: Microsoft OneDrive, Google Drive, Dropbox, Box, iCloud

Virtual Storage is storage that lives "in the cloud", meaning a company provides storage in another location which you have access to via any internet connection, be it wired, wireless, or 2G/3G/4G/LTE/5G data connection. Many devices including iPhone's come with these systems automatically turned on and enabled. In the past several years, many more of these options have become available, and many services have moved to offer free storage, some sources up to 15 GB at no cost to you. Most of these options require little technical knowledge and offer a simple "drag and drop" interface. Below are some of the Pros and Cons of this type of data back up, along with a general step by step instructional guide to using the option offered by MSOE (OneDrive), which offers a full terabyte (1024 GB) of storage.

                Pros:                                                                                Cons:

 · (Mostly) Free                                                                · Data costs

 · Available anywhere with an internet connection          · Not available offline

 · Expandable                                                                   · Vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks and data theft

 · Unlimited Duty Cycle (Doesn't Ware-out)                   · No data recovery options, once its gone, its gone

 · Can be set to automatically store your data                                            

Using Virtual Storage: Microsoft OneDrive

Microsoft OneDrive is accessible via your email and allows you to select what files you want to be stored. We recommend OneDrive because it offers 1024 GB (1TB) of storage, included with your MSOE outlook email. The steps to using OneDrive can be found below.

Step 1: Navigate to: msoe365-my.sharepoint.com

Step 2: Log-In using your normal MSOE credentials. After logging in, your screen should look like this:

Step 3: To Upload files, click "Upload" then follow the instructions on the image below:


Step 4: A dialogue box will popup, then follow the instructions on the image below::

Step 5: Your done!
                                                                                                                                       Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ's)

                                                                                                                              How Often Should I Backup New Documents?

We recommend you back up your documents at least once a week, however when you are working on major projects, or with irreplaceable or large files, backing up your files more often may be appropriate.

How Much Storage do I  Need?

For that, it depends greatly on the amount of data you want to store. Most people are able to store documents, pictures, and music (no programs or games) in about 16 GB of storage. If you want to store large movies (in high definition) or other large files, higher options may be preferable. Regardless, Microsoft OneDrive is able to provide all of the storage most users will ever need.

Have a question, or need help backing up your data? Visit the MSOE-IT Help Desk during our normal business hours, or call us at (414) 277-7288

solution-article.title: How to Update Stubborn AMD Drivers
solution-article.description:
For devices running an AMD Video Card or Processor, often times Windows will not find the appropriate driver update when checked for. These outdated drivers often lead to Blue Screen Errors (Blue Screen of Death). In these situations, the easiest way to force update the drivers is to use AMD's AutoDetect tool.

Step 1: Visit support.amd.com/en-us/download

Step 2: Scroll down the page and locate the option which says "Automatically Detect and Install Your Driver" and select "Download Now"

Step 3: Open the download and follow on-screen prompts. Drivers will automatically update themselves, and it will notify you when all updates have been completed. During this process, the screen may go blank several times. AMD AutoDetect can be set to keep drivers updated, preventing issues in the future.

solution-article.title: Creating Your Own Alumni Account
solution-article.description:
Title:

Creating Your Own Alumni Account


Summary:

A graduated student would like to create an alumni email account.


Solution:

You will need to wait until your degree is conferred by the Registrar’s office before you are able to register for an alumni email account. Receiving your diploma in the mail is a signal this step has been completed.

After your degree has been conferred, head to https://www.msoe.edu/alumni-and-giving/alumni/alumni-services/, and under the section Alumni Email Address, click on View the Instructions. This will open up a PDF file with some more information on it. In the PDF, click on the Sign Up! link to head to the page where you will register for your account.


The registration page requires you fill out some information in order to attach your alumni email with your account. You will need to fill out this information exactly as it appears on your diploma, or else it will not work. You will need to fill out your full first, middle and last name at the time of your attending MSOE, your birthday and the year which you graduated. If you have multiple degrees from MSOE, please use your earliest graduation year.


If you have any issues or any other questions, please feel free to fill out a ticket, and we will be happy to reach out to you.


Updated: 2/9/2018

solution-article.title: Make Blackboard Course Available to Students
solution-article.description: Blackboard shells are created each quarter and are made unavailable to students by default. This allows instructors to build their course before students can see or access it. Instructors can make their courses available when they are ready for students to see their content.

solution-article.title: Using Turnitin within Blackboard
solution-article.description:
Title:

Using Turnitin within Blackboard


Summary:

An instructor in a Blackboard course would like information on setting up and using Turnitin in conjunction with their course.


Solution:

Faculty who are using Blackboard to teach a course may use the Milwaukee School of Engineering’s subscription to the Turnitin Plagiarism Prevention Service from within Blackboard. If desired, faculty can configure Turnitin access in a Blackboard course to include students who are enrolled in the course.


To use Turnitin from within a Blackboard course, follow the steps below. Questions can be directed to Gary Shimek, Director of the Library, at shimek@msoe.edu, or at x7181. Note that the PDF document attached to this solution contains screen captures to assist with this guide.


When logged into your Blackboard course as an instructor, mouse over the Assessments option in the menu bar associated with a course module. A pull-down menu should appear: click on Turnitin Direct Assignment. After you select the Turnitin Direct Assignment option, Blackboard loads the Turnitin Direct Assignment page. Here, you can configure the requirements associated with the specific assignment that you will submit to Turnitin. For example, you need to provide the assignment with a name, and you need to indicate how the assignment will be submitted to Turnitin. You can upload a file to Turnitin from Blackboard (select File Upload), or you can copy-and-paste a text submission (select Text submission) – or you can submit with both methods (select Any Submission Type). You can also configure other advanced assignment options.

When you have completed filling out the Turnitin Direct Assignment page, scroll to the bottom of the page, and click the Submit button. Don’t worry! If you subsequently decide that you want to change an option in your assignment configuration, after the assignment is implemented, you can always modify your assignment requirements. After you complete the configuration of your assignment, Blackboard creates the assignment as an item at the bottom of the page. The item features the name of your assignment, along with a live View Assignment link. You can  move the placement of the item by right-clicking it and selecting the Move option. This item is viewable by you and your students. To view the details of the assignment, and to begin submitting work to Turnitin, click on the View Assignment link.

When you click on the View Assignment link, you can then see the details concerning the assignment. In the tool bar associated with the assignment, click on Submit to submit a document to Turnitin. Click on Submissions Inbox to see the documents that have been submitted to Turnitin. Click on Modify to reload the Turnitin Direct Assignment page in order to change the requirements associated with the assignment.

When you click on the assignment Submit option, Blackboard loads the Submit page. Depending on how you configured the assignment, Blackboard will ask you to select a submission option, or it will present you with either a File Upload default or a Text Submission default. After you select the submission option, Blackboard asks you to supply a student’s name. This is the name of the student whose document you wish to submit to Turnitin. Blackboard allows you only to select the name of a student enrolled in your Blackboard course. Blackboard does not allow you to select the name of a student who is not associated with an e-mail address. After you have entered the required information, click the Submit button to submit the document to Turnitin.

After you click the Submit button, Blackboard takes you back to the Assignment page. Click on the Submissions Inbox option to see a listing of the documents that you have submitted to Turnitin. See The Submissions Inbox lists each document, along with the date and time submitted. In addition, a Similarity score is associated with each document, as well as a Grade, and two other icons, including a document icon and a trash can icon. Click on the document icon to download a copy of the document as you submitted it; click on the trash can to remove the document.

The Similarity score is a percent score that Turnitin assigns to the document. This score indicates Turnitin’s assessment of the percent of plagiarism in the document. The Similarity score of a document needs to be evaluated by studying the actual plagiarism report associated with the document. You can study the report by clicking on the Similarity score associated with the document. As seen in Figure 9, when you mouse over the score, you should see a View Originality Report. Click on the Similarity score to see the originality report.

Updated: 2/12/2018

After you select the submission option, Blackboard asks you to supply a student’s name. This is the name of the student whose document you wish to submit to Turnitin. Blackboard allows you only to select the name of a student enrolled in your Blackboard course. Blackboard does not allow you to select the name of a student who is not associated with an e-mail address. After you have entered the required information, click the Submit button to submit the document to Turnitin. After you click the Submit button, Blackboard takes you back to the Assignment page. Click on the Submissions Inbox option to see a listing of the documents that you have submitted to Turnitin. See The Submissions Inbox lists each document, along with the date and time submitted. In addition, a Similarity score is associated with each document, as well as a Grade, and two other icons, including a document icon and a trash can icon. Click on the document icon to download a copy of the document as you submitted it; click on the trash can to remove the document. The Similarity score is a percent score that Turnitin assigns to the document. This score indicates Turnitin’s assessment of the percent of plagiarism in the document. The Similarity score of a document needs to be evaluated by studying the actual plagiarism report associated with the document. You can study the report by clicking on the Similarity score associated with the document. As seen in Figure 9, when you mouse over the score, you should see a View Originality Report. Click on the Similarity score to see the originality report. Updated: 2/12/2018

solution-article.title: Adding a Shared Mailbox to Your Outlook Profile
solution-article.description:
Title:

Adding a Shared Mailbox to Your Outlook Profile


Summary:

A user would like to know how to set up a shared mailbox to attach to their Outlook profile.


Solution:

In Outlook, go to File -> Account Settings. Click the New button in Account Settings.



Type in the E-mail Address of the shared mailbox in the E-mail Address: field.  Leave ALL other fields BLANK. Click Next.



Let Outlook search for the account and once it finds it, you will be prompted to enter the account name and password.  In this window, remove the shared mailbox account name and enter your email account and your password.  


- Note: If Outlook cannot locate the account, please recheck.  You might have mistyped the account name.



Once you complete this step, the new profile will show up under your profile in Account Settings.  You can change it to be the default profile by highlighting the account and clicking on the "Set as Default" option in Account Settings.


- Note: If this fails, you might not have access to the shared mailbox account.  Please verify that you have full access and send as access to the account before trying again.


Updated: 2/12/2018
solution-article.desc-un-html:

- Note: If Outlook cannot locate the account, please recheck. You might have mistyped the account name.
Once you complete this step, the new profile will show up under your profile in Account Settings. You can change it to be the default profile by highlighting the account and clicking on the "Set as Default" option in Account Settings.
- Note: If this fails, you might not have access to the shared mailbox account. Please verify that you have full access and send as access to the account before trying again.
Updated: 2/12/2018

solution-article.title: Creating An Outlook Email Group
solution-article.description:
Title:

Creating an Outlook Email Group


Summary:

A user would like to create and edit an email group that is attached to their Outlook profile.


Solution:

To create a new group in Outlook, on the home page, open your address book and select Contacts. Click File and then select New Entry. Make the entry type to be New Contact Group. In the Put This Entry field select In the Contacts (this is the default location). Select ok. Select a name for the group. Click the add member button and add members as needed. Click Save, and then Close.


To edit the group, find the group in the address book. Right click and hit properties. Add and remove members as desired. Click Save, and then Close.


Updated: 2/13/2018

solution-article.title: Encrypting Email Messages Sent to MSOE Users
solution-article.description:
Title:

Encrypting Email Messages Sent to MSOE Users


Summary:

A MSOE user would like to send an encrypted email to another MSOE user.


Solution:

In order to encrypt email messages you will need to add the word Encrypted: in the subject.  This allows Office 365 to recognize that you wish to have the email encrypted and it will perform the encryption for you.  Any attachment to your email will be encrypted as well.

Caveat: Email encryption will work automatically for anyone with the @msoe.edu suffix, but if you would like to send encrypted emails to someone outside of the organization, the person will not have the authority to view the email. This authority can only be granted on a person by person basis and will need to be done by the IT department.

Updated: 2/13/2018

solution-article.title: Managing a Shared Mailbox
solution-article.description:
Title:

Managing a Shared Mailbox


Summary:

A user would like information on accessing and emailing from a shared mailbox.


Solution:

If you are using the Outlook desktop app:


If you have access to a shared mailbox, then it will appear as an additional account under your personal account. If it does not show up automatically then log off, and log back on again while wired to the network. If that doesn’t work try rebooting your computer. If you still don’t see the account, follow these steps to manually add it.


Go to File -> Account Settings -> Account Settings. Make sure your name is highlighted and click Change. Click More Settings and then the Advanced tab. Under Mailboxes add the shared mailbox you need access to. Click Apply and then Ok and close out of the rest of the windows.

If you need to send from that account, create a new email, select Options and make sure From is highlighted. If you haven’t sent from email address in the past, you will need to select “Other Email Address” and look it up in the address book. You’ll only have to do this once, and afterwards the From option will always appear.


If you are using the Outlook web app:


Log into webmail as yourself at outlook.com/msoe.edu. In the top right corner click on your picture to open another mailbox. Once you open the new mailbox you will be working as that user.


Updated: 2/15/2018

solution-article.title: Outlook 2016 is Stuck at "Processing"
solution-article.description:
Title:

Outlook 2016 is Stuck at "Processing"


Summary:

When attempting to open the Outlook 2016 desktop application, the application hangs at "processing" and never opens.


Solution:

Deleting the data files for your Outlook profile will prevent this from happening without affecting your emails. You can find the data files under C:\Users\<insert_user_name>\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Outlook, with <insert_user_name> being your MSOE username. The AppData folder is marked as Hidden by default, so you will be unable to simply navigate to the folder. You can get around this by either pasting the file path (C:\Users\<insert_user_name>\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Outlook) into the address bar in File Explorer, or by clicking on the View tab, and checking Hidden Items under the Show/Hide category.


Once you get to the Outlook folder, delete the Outlook data files. These are the files that have a type listed as "Outlook Data File", or have a file extension of ".nst" or ".ost". Deleting these will alert Outlook to recreate them upon startup, and will stop the issue of Outlook hanging at "processing".


Updated: 2/14/2018

solution-article.title: Outlook App Error Disconnected - Cannot Connect to Microsoft Exchange - Can't Reach the Mail Server
solution-article.description:
Title:

Outlook App Error Disconnected - Cannot Connect to Microsoft Exchange - Can't Reach the Mail Server


Summary:

A user's Outlook application will not update with new emails, and on the bottom the error message "Outlook App Error Disconnected - Cannot Connect to Microsoft Exchange - Can't Reach the Mail Server" is displayed.


Solution:

The saved Outlook password needs to be updated with the user's current password. One way to do it is to delete the Outlook password that the windows previously saved on your laptop. Once it is deleted, when you reopen the outlook, it should ask for password where in you enter the current password.

In order to deleted the stored old Outlook password, click the Start button, type-in "Credential Manager" and hit the Enter button. A dialogue box should appear. In the dialogue box, under "Windows Credentials", click the vault or vaults that contains Outlook credentials. Click Remove from Vault. Hit 'yes' when it asks for the confirmation to delete those credentials.


Reopen Outlook. Now you should get a pop-up window asking you to enter your credentials. Once you enter your current password, your Outlook should get connected to Microsoft Exchange and your inbox should get updated with recent emails.


Updated: 2/14/2018

In the dialogue box, under "Windows Credentials", click the vault or vaults that contains Outlook credentials. Click Remove from Vault. Hit 'yes' when it asks for the confirmation to delete those credentials.
Reopen Outlook. Now you should get a pop-up window asking you to enter your credentials. Once you enter your current password, your Outlook should get connected to Microsoft Exchange and your inbox should get updated with recent emails.

solution-article.title: Setting Up Alumni Email on Android Devices
solution-article.description:
Title:

Setting Up Alumni Email on Android Devices


Summary:

A user would like to set up their alumni email on an Android device.


Solution:

First, IMAP in Gmail needs to be enabled. To do this, sign in to your alumni account on a computer. Click the gear icon in the upper-right and select Settings. Click on the Forwarding and POP/IMAP tab. Under IMAP Access, select Enable IMAP. Click on the Save Changes button on the bottom of the screen.

On the Android device, open the Email application. Enter your email address and password, and tap on the Manual Setup button. Select IMAP account. Enter the following for the incoming server settings on the next screen:

User name: This will be your user name, which will be the same as your email address, but without the "@gmail.com"
Password: This will be the same password for your email address.
IMAP Server: imap.gmail.com
Port: 993 (If this doesn't work, it could be 143 or, rarely, 585)
Security type: SSL

Tap on the Next button. Enter the following for the outgoing server settings on the next screen:

SMTP server: smtp.gmail.com
Port: 465 (If this doesn't work, it could be 25 or, rarely, 2525)
Security type: SSL
Uncheck the required sign-in box

Tap on the Next button. On the next screen, select any setting for the frequency and tap on the Next button. Finally, give the account a name and input the desired display name, and the tap on the Done button. The email account should now be viewable on the Android device.

Updated: 2/15/2018

solution-article.title: Setting Up MSOE Email on Android Phones
solution-article.description:
Title:

Setting Up MSOE Email on Android Devices


Summary:

A user would like to set up their MSOE email account on the default email application for an Android device.


Solution:

On the Android device, open Settings and navigate to the Accounts tab. On the bottom, tap on Add Account. Select Microsoft Exchange, and enter your MSOE email address and password. Depending on your device, security notifications may pop up. Tap on OK to close any that do.

After closing any notifications, the device should be at an Account Options page. Set the desired settings for the email account and tap on Next. On the page that opens, scroll to the bottom and tap on Activate. Enter a name for the account and tap on Next. If an update for security is prompted, tap on OK to update. The email account should now be available on the Android device.

solution-article.title: Setting Up MSOE Email on Apple Mail for Mac Computers
solution-article.description:
Title:

Setting Up MSOE Email on Apple Mail for Mac Computers


Summary:

A user would like to access their MSOE email address on Apple Mail on a Mac computer.


Solution:

If the Mac computer is on OS X Mavericks, then the computer will need to be disconnected from the internet for the duration of these steps. A message may pop up that the Exchange server could not be contacted; this is to be expected.


On the Mac computer, open System Preferences, and select Internet Accounts. In the window that opens, select Exchange and click Continue. In the window that opens, fill out the settings as follows:


Name: The name that you want to associate with the email account

Email Address: The MSOE email address

Domain Password: The password of the MSOE email address


Click Continue. In the window that opens, fill out the account settings as follows:


Description: MSOE

Username: The MSOE email address

Password: The password of the MSOE email address

Server Address: outlook.office365.com


Click Continue. In the window that opens, select which items are allowed to sync with Apple Mail. Click Done.


At this point, if the Mac computer is on OS X Mavericks, the computer can be reconnected to the internet. Open Mail, and the emails will begin to populate.


Updated: 2/15/2018

solution-article.title: Using the Updated Fax Service
solution-article.description:
Title:

Using the Updated Fax Service


Summary:

A user would like to use the fax service through their MSOE email.


Solution:

Anyone can send a fax directly through their MSOE email. As an example, to send a fax to the local number 333-4444, address an email to 3334444@fax.msoe.edu. The cover page can be populated by setting an email subject and filling the body. Then just attach a word, excel, or PDF document to the email and it will arrive at the destination fax machine as a normal fax. To fax hard copy of a document, first scan it to your email to turn it into a PDF file, then send it as an attachment.

To send a long distance fax, address it to the 10 digit number plus a county code, so 11 digits in total. As an example, a fax to the US number (555)333-4444 would be addressed to 15553334444@fax.msoe.edu. Internal faxing is now not much more than email, but can be accomplished by addressing the 7 digit number. As an example, to send a fax to IT, it would be sent to 2777495@fax.msoe.edu, as the fax extension for IT is x7495.

Incoming faxes will be received by email as well. This is being handled in a number of ways, but most departments are using either a department email account or someone in the department will manage the faxes with their email account directly. This will allow people with fax numbers on their business cards to still receive faxes from those numbers.


Updated: 2/15/2018

solution-article.title: Sending an email as another person within Outlook
solution-article.description:
If a user has access to joint or shared mailboxes and would like to send a email as that account, they may do so from the Outlook desktop application by doing the following


1). Select 'new email'

2). Go to the 'options' tab

3). Enable 'Form' in the 'Show Fields' section

      *A from drop down menu will appear next to the name of the sender

4). Select the drop down and pick the address you wish to send from, if it isn't on the list select 'other email address' and search.

solution-folder.name: Hardware
solution-folder.description: This folder contains material pertaining to hardware procedures that are public to customers.

solution-article.title: Repairing Corrupted Partition on Flash Drive or Hard Drive with Linux - File Recovery
solution-article.description:
This is a solution I used to successfully recover files from a corrupted USB drive:

Causes:
Removing storage medium without it being properly ejected or unmounted, physical degradation of storage medium, etc.
Symptoms:
Unable to view partition, OS asking to format partition or drive
Solution:
For this particular solution, you will need a Linux computer. It is okay to live boot Linux on a Windows or Mac computer. You may have to consult internet tutorials for specific instructions on live booting Linux
If you ever get a "Permission denied" error while following this tutorial type "sudo" before the command you are trying to run.
Plug the drive into the Linux computer (this is unnecessary if you are using a Linux live session to repair a partition on the computer's internal hard drive). Open the terminal. Run the following command:
lsblk
This command will list all the drives connected.
Your primary hard drive should be /dev/sda and /dev/sda1 or any number will be a partition on the drive. The "/dev/sda" is the volume label.
Any secondary drive will be /dev/sdb /dev/sdc and so on. If you are running Linux off of a USB, the Linux USB will probably be /dev/sdb and the other flash drive should be /dev/sdc
Try to figure out the volume label for the partition you want to repair. The "lsblk" will show the size of all the partition so it helps to know the size ahead of time to identify the correct partition.
Depending on the Linux distro you are using, you should be able to open the graphical File Manager program (think Windows Explorer or Finder on a Mac) and see which partitions were mounted. See if any of these are the partition you are trying to recover (although if it is corrupted is unlikely that Linux will auto-mount it for you). You also can try this command to list partitions:
sudo fdisk -l
Once you know the label for the partition you are trying to recover move on. The following procedure is assuming the label for the corrupted partition is /dev/sdc1. Replace this with your corrupted partition label as needed.
You can run a repair on this partition with this command (replacing /dev/sdc1 with your partition of course):
sudo fsck /dev/sdc1
You may have to run additional "fsck" commands. Run the command "man fsck" to get a manual page on the program for more advanced options.
If it is repaired, it should show up in the file manager program. If not, you may have to manually mount the partition.
In order to do that, run these commands:

"cd /mnt"
This will change your current directory to the root "/" directory

"sudo mkdir /mnt/mountpoint"
This will make a new folder in the "/mnt" directory called "mountpoint"

"sudo mount /dev/sdc /mnt/mountpoint"
This will mount the partition /dev/sdc to /mnt/mountpoint. Open /mnt/mountpoint to view the contents. You may have to specify a file system for the partition. For example, for a NTFS (Windows file system) partition:

"sudo mount -t ntfs /dev/sdc /mnt/mountpoint"
If this does not work, you can also try "force mount" by appending "-o force" to the end of the command.

For example: "sudo mount -t ext4 /dev/sda1 /mnt/mountpoint -o force" will force mount an ext4 filesystem from /dev/sda1 to the directory /mnt/mountpoint

Once mounted you can copy the files to a backup although the partition may have been completely repaired with "fsck"
To un-mount (like clicking "eject drive" in Windows)
Type "sudo umount /mnt/mountpoint" or use the eject button in the GUI.
solution-article.desc-un-html:
This is a solution I used to successfully recover files from a corrupted USB drive:
Causes: Removing storage medium without it being properly ejected or unmounted, physical degradation of storage medium, etc. Symptoms: Unable to view partition, OS asking to format partition or drive
Solution: For this particular solution, you will need a Linux computer. It is okay to live boot Linux on a Windows or Mac computer. You may have to consult internet tutorials for specific instructions on live booting Linux If you ever get a "Permission denied" error while following this tutorial type "sudo" before the command you are trying to run.
Plug the drive into the Linux computer (this is unnecessary if you are using a Linux live session to repair a partition on the computer's internal hard drive). Open the terminal. Run the following command: lsblk This command will list all the drives connected. Your primary hard drive should be /dev/sda and /dev/sda1 or any number will be a partition on the drive. The "/dev/sda" is the volume label.
Any secondary drive will be /dev/sdb /dev/sdc and so on. If you are running Linux off of a USB, the Linux USB will probably be /dev/sdb and the other flash drive should be /dev/sdc
Try to figure out the volume label for the partition you want to repair. The "lsblk" will show the size of all the partition so it helps to know the size ahead of time to identify the correct partition.
Depending on the Linux distro you are using, you should be able to open the graphical File Manager program (think Windows Explorer or Finder on a Mac) and see which partitions were mounted. See if any of these are the partition you are trying to recover (although if it is corrupted is unlikely that Linux will auto-mount it for you). You also can try this command to list partitions:
sudo fdisk -l
Once you know the label for the partition you are trying to recover move on. The following procedure is assuming the label for the corrupted partition is /dev/sdc1. Replace this with your corrupted partition label as needed.
You can run a repair on this partition with this command (replacing /dev/sdc1 with your partition of course): sudo fsck /dev/sdc1 You may have to run additional "fsck" commands. Run the command "man fsck" to get a manual page on the program for more advanced options.
If it is repaired, it should show up in the file manager program. If not, you may have to manually mount the partition. In order to do that, run these commands:
"cd /mnt" This will change your current directory to the root "/" directory
"sudo mkdir /mnt/mountpoint" This will make a new folder in the "/mnt" directory called "mountpoint"
"sudo mount /dev/sdc /mnt/mountpoint"
This will mount the partition /dev/sdc to /mnt/mountpoint. Open /mnt/mountpoint to view the contents. You may have to specify a file system for the partition. For example, for a NTFS (Windows file system) partition:
"sudo mount -t ntfs /dev/sdc /mnt/mountpoint" If this does not work, you can also try "force mount" by appending "-o force" to the end of the command.
For example: "sudo mount -t ext4 /dev/sda1 /mnt/mountpoint -o force" will force mount an ext4 filesystem from /dev/sda1 to the directory /mnt/mountpoint
Once mounted you can copy the files to a backup although the partition may have been completely repaired with "fsck"
To un-mount (like clicking "eject drive" in Windows) Type "sudo umount /mnt/mountpoint" or use the eject button in the GUI.

solution-folder.description: This folder contains materials that pertain to laptop procedures that are not public to customers.

solution-article.title: Any Model - Checking For and Correcting Hard Drive Errors
solution-article.description:
Title:

Any Model - Checking For and Correcting Hard Drive Errors


Summary:

A computer is running slowly or otherwise not functioning properly, and it is suspected that the computer has hard drive errors.


Solution:

Note: Always backup your data in case of full hard drive failure. This solution will detect all errors on the specified drive but may require multiple attempts to fix them and may take a long while to finish. Also, not all errors can be fixed if the drive is failing. If the error is not fixed after 2 or 3 passes, this may be a sign that hard drive failure is imminent.


To run the drive test, open an elevated command prompt. This is done by searching for command prompt in the windows search bar, then right clicking on command prompt and clicking Run as Administrator. In the window that opens click Yes. Then type the following command in the command prompt window: chkdsk <enter the drive you want to test>: /f/r .  For example to test the C:/ drive the command will be: chkdsk C: /f/r . Follow the instructions on the screen to start the test and repair phases.


The test will take anywhere from 10 minutes to a couple hours.


Updated: 2/15/2018

solution-article.title: Any Model - Clearing Windows 10 Wi-Fi Network Connection
solution-article.description:
Title:

Any Model - Clearing Windows 10 Wi-Fi Network Connection


Summary:

A computer is having issues with connecting to a wireless network due to Windows 10 storing outdated credentials.


Solution:

Open the Start Menu and type Settings, and then press Enter. click on Network & Internet and scroll all the way to the bottom of the available Wi-Fi networks page. Click on manage Wi-Fi settings, and scroll down to the bottom of the page. Under Manage Known Networks there will be a list of all the Wi-Fi networks you’ve connected to. Clicking on one of them will give an option to forget the network, which will remove any stored credentials, preventing Windows 10 from attempting to use any outdated ones. After forgetting the network, attempt to connect to it again.


Updated: 2/15/2018

solution-article.title: Any Model - Common Problems with Power and Charging
solution-article.description:
Title:

Any Model - Common Problems with Power and Charging


Summary:

A laptop is having issues with turning on or holding a charge.


Solution:

Laptop does not turn on:
Perform a hard reset. This is done by removing the battery and charger, and holding the power button down for 30 seconds. This drains any residual electricity that the laptop may have. Attempt to turn the laptop back on.

Laptop does not charge:
Perform a hard reset. This is done by removing the battery and charger, and holding the power button down for 30 seconds. This drains any residual electricity that the laptop may have. Ensure that the outlet is providing power, by testing with another device that is known to be working. Ensure that the charger is plugged in to the computer and the outlet properly, and ensure that it is providing power by testing with another laptop. Attempt to turn the laptop back on.

Laptop shuts down or turns off at random intervals:
Perform a hard reset. This is done by removing the battery and charger, and holding the power button down for 30 seconds. This drains any residual electricity that the laptop may have. Install any Windows Updates that are available. If there are any, there will be an Install Updates and Shut Down option in the shut down menu in the Start menu. Attempt to turn the laptop back on.

Laptop turns on briefly before turning off:
Perform a hard reset. This is done by removing the battery and charger, and holding the power button down for 30 seconds. This drains any residual electricity that the laptop may have. Unplug all external devices. This includes the charger, Ethernet cords, USB devices and any other cords that are not the laptop itself. Attempt to turn the laptop back on.

If after attempting these steps the issue persists, bring the laptop to the IT Department.


Updated: 2/15/2018

solution-article.title: Any Model - Computer Running Slow
solution-article.description:
Title:

Any Model - Computer Running Slow


Summary:

A computer is running slow, and there are no obvious programs running that would account for the slowdown.


Solution:

First, check for any Windows Updates. If there are any, install the updates and restart the computer. If that does not resolve the issue, the attempt the following steps.

If your Drive is getting full, try transferring your data to your Hard Drive or delete unnecessary items. Uninstall any unnecessary software, by right clicking on the Start menu and clicking Apps and Features. Download CCleaner (https://www.piriform.com/ccleaner/download). This deletes unnecessary temporary files and cookies that use disk space.

 

If that doesn't boost the computer speed, it could possibly be malware. In order to fix that, you can use MalwareBytes (https://www.malwarebytes.com/mwb-download/thankyou/)


Updated: 2/15/2018

solution-article.title: Any Model - Computer Will Not Stay On Without Being Plugged In
solution-article.description:
Title:

Any Model - Computer Will Not Stay On Without Being Plugged In


Summary:

A laptop will immediately shut down when disconnected from the charger. This could possibly be a sign of battery failure.


Solution:

The first step is to make sure the laptop battery is seated correctly. Make sure all the latches of the battery are in the computer base and the battery is aligned in parallel with the bottom of the computer. If this is not the case, try to realign the battery and try again.


If the previous step fails, check if your laptop charger is working. This can be done by using another charger (either a friend's or from the IT Helpdesk). If you see the charging light turn on (using the other charger) and this is not the case with your charger, stop by the Helpdesk and to get a new charger.


The next step is to check if Windows recognizes the battery. Start by unplugging the battery and charging cable. Push down the power button for 5 seconds and then put the battery back in. Plug in your charger and let your laptop charge for a few minutes (around 5-15 minutes). Unplug the power cable and check if the laptop will turn on.


Updated: 2/15/2018

solution-article.title: Any Model - Disabling Startup Programs in Windows 10
solution-article.description:
Title:

Any Model - Disabling Startup Programs in Windows 10


Summary:

Upon startup, a laptop will start running multiple different programs. When too many programs are marked to begin on startup, the laptop could start to slow down on startup to unreasonable levels until every program is finished starting. Disabling startup programs will resolve this issue.


Solution:

Open Task Manager. This can be done by either pressing the Ctrl + Shift + Esc buttons at the same time, or by right clicking the task bar at the bottom of the screen and clicking Task Manager. If there is a More Details button at the bottom of the window that opens, click it. Open the Startup tab at the top of the window. Select any programs that you would like to disable and click the Disable button at the bottom of the window. Restart your computer.

Updated: 2/16/2018

solution-article.title: Any Model - Freeing Up Hard Drive Space
solution-article.description:
Title:

Any Model - Freeing Up Hard Drive Space


Summary:

Running out of hard drive space will prevent users from being able to create new files, install new software and even could prevent software from running. There are a few ways to free up hard drive space and prevent this from happening.


Solution:

Move files not necessary for function, such as videos and pictures, off of your hard drive and on to a cloud service. MSOE provides 10 GB of storage to all students, staff and faculty on Box.

Uninstall any unnecessary programs. Programs such as the Autodesk suite take up large amounts of storage space on the hard drive. Right click on the Start button on the bottom left of the computer and select Apps and Features. This will provide a list of programs installed on the computer. This list can be sorted by size, in order to prioritize the largest programs that would provide the most space when uninstalled. Any programs that are uninstalled can be reinstalled if it is later discovered that the program is needed again.

Perform a Windows Disk Cleanup. Open the Start menu, type Disk Cleanup and press the Enter button. This will remove any extraneous files on the hard drive, such as temporary files and cached internet pages. Select the types of files to remove and click the Clean Up System Files button.

If cleaning up the hard drive becomes too large of a task, then a reimage may be in order. This will delete every file on the laptop, but will regain all of the space on the hard drive and provide the laptop with a clean slate. Come to the IT Helpdesk in order to get a reimage.

Updated: 2/16/2018

solution-article.title: Any Model - Keyboard Not Working or Typing Wrong Letters
solution-article.description:
Title:

Any Model - Keyboard Not Working or Typing Wrong Letters


Summary:

A user is experiencing issues with their keyboard such as it not functioning, typing the wrong characters or opening windows when pressing keys, and there is no obvious physical damage to the keyboard.


Solution:

Press the Windows key (in between Alt and FN), to ensure that the laptop does not think that the key is being held down. Perform a hard reset. This is done by removing the battery and charger, and holding the power button down for 30 seconds. This drains any residual electricity that the laptop may have. Power the laptop back on and check for keyboard functionality.

If these solutions do not resolve the issue, then it is likely a hardware issue rather than a software issue. Bring the laptop to the IT Helpdesk in order to get it replaced.

Updated: 2/16/2018

solution-article.title: Any Model - Resolving Issues with Connecting to WiFi
solution-article.description:
Title:

Any Model - Resolving Issues with Connecting to WiFi


Summary:

There are various issues that would prevent a laptop from connecting to WiFi. This solution will detail resolving a few of them.


Solution:

First, ensure that the left most button in the upper right-hand corner of the laptop keyboard is white. If it is illuminated orange, press it to make it become white, and this should enable the Wireless connection. If the button seems to have no effect, ensure first that when you click on the internet icon in the lower right-hand corner that it is showing networks. If not, click the 'Network Settings' link and make sure Wi-Fi is turned on. If it is turned off, turn it back on with the switch, and this should allow the laptop to connect to the network again. 


Open the Control Panel by opening the Start menu, typing Control Panel and pressing the Enter key. Click on Network and Internet, and then on Network and Sharing Center. On the left side, click Change adapter settings. This should open up a new window. In this window, see all of the connection methods are shown, with Wireless most likely being the furthest right. Right-click the icon labeled Wireless and, if there is an option that says Enable, click on it.

If the laptop is still unable to connect, then open the 'Device Manager by opening the Start menu, typing Device Manager and pressing the Enter key. Open the tab marked Network Adapters. Under this tab, there should be a device with Intel Wireless or Wi-Fi in the name. Right-click this choice and select Update driver software. In the window that opens, click on the Search Automatically for Updated Driver Software. Continue with the prompts until done. Once finished, the laptop will need to be restarted in order for the changes to take effect.

If the laptop is still unable to connect, then take it to the IT Helpdesk in order to get further assistance.


Updated: 2/19/2018

solution-article.title: External Monitor - Blurry Screen
solution-article.description:
Title:

External Monitor - Blurry Screen


Summary:

When swapping from Windows 7 to Windows 10, it is common to experience issues with blurry displays due to differing zoom or resolution settings between the displays.


Solution:

The solution will be different depending on if the display is being used in extended mode or duplicate mode.

Extended Mode:
Right click on the desktop and click Display Settings. A window will open up with settings for each display. At the top of the window are multiple rectangles with numbers in them representing each display. Click a rectangle to select it, and check the Change the Size of Text, Apps, and Other Items setting below. If the setting is different for each display, set the setting to the same value for all displays.

Duplicate Mode:
Right click on the desktop and click Display Settings. A window will open up with settings for each display. At the top of the window are multiple rectangles with numbers in them representing each display. Click the rectangle that represents the blurry display, and scroll down to the Resolution setting. Change this setting until a value that does not cause the display to be blurry is found.

Updated: 2/16/18

solution-article.title: External Monitor - General Troubleshooting Issues
solution-article.description:
Title:

External Monitor - General Troubleshooting Issues


Summary:

An external monitor is not functional, but there is no obvious issues with it.


Solution:

Check that the monitor turns on and that both the power cable and the input are plugged in securely. It is not uncommon for monitors to become unplugged by unintentionally bumping into them. If the monitor turns on but does not connect to the computer, ensure that the computer is set to Duplicate or Extend mode. This can be done by pressing the Windows + P keys together. If the correct mode is selected, try using a different input cable to ensure that the cable is not non-functional. If changing the cable does not work, try using a different monitor to ensure that the monitor is non-functional.

If the computer is able to connect to other monitors, try updating the graphics driver. Open the Start menu and type Device Manager, and press the Enter button. Locate the graphics driver (it will be under Display Adapters), right click it and click Update Driver. In the window that appears, click Search Automatically for Updated Driver Software. Follow the prompts that appear.

Updated: 2/16/18

HP ZBook G3/HP 840 G3 - Enabling and Disabling Scroll Lock

A user would like to enable or disable scroll lock on their G3 model laptop.


Solution:

Open the on screen keyboard. This can be done by opening the Start menu, typing On Screen Keyboard and pressing the Enter button. In the window that opens up, click on the ScrLk button to toggle scroll lock.

solution-article.title: HP ZBook G3/HP 840 G3 - FN Brightness Control Keys Not Working
solution-article.description:
Title:

HP ZBook G3/HP 840 G3 - FN Brightness Control Keys Not Working


Summary:

The brightness control buttons on a laptop are not working, but every other function key is functional.


Solution:

Open the Start menu, type Device Manager and press the Enter button. Find Display Adapters and expand it. Right click on the driver that has NVIDIA in the name and click the Uninstall Device button. This will bring up a confirmation box, click the OK button (Do NOT check the box asking if you wish to delete the driver software). Restart the computer.

After the computer restarts, return to the Display Adapters in Device Manager. Right click the driver again and click the Update Driver Software... button. In the window that opens up, select Search Automatically for Updated Driver Software. After that is finished running, restart the computer.

Updated: 2/16/18

Title:
HP ZBook G3/HP 840 G3 - FN Brightness Control Keys Not Working
Summary: The brightness control buttons on a laptop are not working, but every other function key is functional.
Solution: Open the Start menu, type Device Manager and press the Enter button. Find Display Adapters and expand it. Right click on the driver that has NVIDIA in the name and click the Uninstall Device button. This will bring up a confirmation box, click the OK button (Do NOT check the box asking if you wish to delete the driver software). Restart the computer. After the computer restarts, return to the Display Adapters in Device Manager. Right click the driver again and click the Update Driver Software... button. In the window that opens up, select Search Automatically for Updated Driver Software. After that is finished running, restart the computer. Updated: 2/16/18

solution-article.title: Installing and Using the GlobalProtect Windows 64-bit VPN Agent for Windows
solution-article.description:
Title:

Installing and Using the GlobalProtect Windows 64-bit VPN Agent for Windows


Summary:

In order to use certain MSOE resources, a connection to the network is required. Normally, this would require being on-campus, but access to these resources is possible off-campus by the use of our VPN, GlobalProtect.


Solution:

Note that users are not able to connect to GlobalProtect while on the campus network. This shouldn't be an issue, as the purpose of connecting to GlobalProtect is to connect to the campus network from off-campus.

There are two methods for acquiring the new client software, depending on if it is being downloaded on- or off-campus. On campus, the client is available from Software Center. On an MSOE laptop, open the Start menu, type Software Center and press the Enter key. In the window that opens, on the top right search for GlobalProtect (one word), click on the icon that appears and click on the Install button.

Off campus, the client is available from bit.ly/msoevpn This redirects directly to the install page. (No need to confuse users with typing https:// as you had to do with an old solution)

Upon downloading the new client installer, run the program and select the defaults. Once the new client is installed and opened, click on the Connect button, and a window will open asking for your login credentials. The Portal should already be populated, but if it is not, then the Portal is sslvpn.msoe.edu.



The laptop should then connect to GlobalProtect. An icon should then appear in the top right of the Home tab. This can be clicked on in order to change or remove the credentials that are being used for GlobalProtect to connect. The Connect button will change to say Disconnect, and can be clicked on in order to disconnect from the network.


Updated: 5/11/2018

solution-article.title: Setting Up an MSOE VPN for Mac
solution-article.description:
Title:

Setting Up an MSOE VPN for Mac


Summary:

In order to use certain MSOE resources, a connection to the network is required. Normally, this would require being on-campus, but access to these resources is possible off-campus by the use of a VPN.


Solution:

Open System Preferences and click on Network. Click on the + button on the bottom left of the window. In the popup, input the following options:

Interface: VPN
VPN Type: Cisco IPSec
Service Name: MSOE SSL VPN

Click on the Create button. In the window that opens, input the following options:

Server Address: sslvpn.msoe.edu
Account Name: This is the MSOE username of the account to connect
Password: This is the password of the MSOE username

Check the Show VPN Status in Menu Bar box and click on the Authentication Settings... button. In the previous window, select the MSOE SSL VPN on the left side and input the following options:

Shared Secret: raiders
Group Name: MSOE

Click on the OK button. In the previous window, click on the Apply button.


Updated: 2/19/2018

solution-article.title: Clearing the old password out of global protect v4
solution-article.description:
To clear the credentials out of global protect by double clicking on the tray tool for global protect (the little globe) on the windows taskbar. Then go to the home tab in the global protect panel and in the box that contains the portal information 'sslvpn.msoe.edu' and the 'connect' button it will show your username in the upper right hand corner. Click on the button on the right of your username and click ok when asked to clear the credentials. Now the next time your off campus and hit connect you will be asked for your username and your new password.



-CW

solution-article.title: Connecting to the MSOE VPN from Linux
solution-article.description:
Connecting to the MSOE VPN from Linux

Normally, GlobalProtect is used to connect to the MSOE VPN. Unfortunately, when if you go to download it, there are only versions for Windows and Macs. Fortunately, Linux can still connect to VPN with some terminal commands.

Google “what is my ip” to get a baseline IP address.


First, install the “vpnc” package. Run one of the following commands depending on your Linux distribution..

Ubuntu/Debian based:
sudo apt-get install network-manager-vpnc

RHEL/Fedora based:

sudo dnf install vpnc


Arch Linux based:

sudo pacman -S networkmanager-vpnc

Solus Linux:

sudo eopkg install vpnc


After installing the package run this command:

sudo vpnc

Answer the prompts as shown (answers are bolded):

Enter IPSec gateway address: sslvpn.msoe.edu
Enter IPSec ID for sslvpn.msoe.edu: MSOE
Enter IPSec secret for MSOE@sslvpn.msoe.edu: raiders
Enter username for sslvpn.msoe.edu:yourusername
Enter password for username@sslvpn.msoe.edu:yourpassword

Replace “yourusername” and “yourpassword” with your MSOE credentials.


NOTE: Nothing will show up when you are typing in “raiders” and “yourpassword”, just keep typing and hit enter when you are done.


After 10 seconds, hit Control+C if no message appears saying vpnc process started in the background (I had to do this on Ubuntu but not Fedora).


Google “what is my ip” to see if it has changed.


To end the VPN connection:

sudo killall vpnc

Google “what is my ip” to see if it has changed.
To end the VPN connection:

solution-folder.description: This folder contains materials that pertain to network drive procedures that are public to customers.

solution-article.title: Mapping MSOE Network Drives
solution-article.description:
Title:

Mapping MSOE Network Drives


Summary:

Network drives are storage devices that allow for users to store files on a server and potentially share with other users that have access to the drive.


Solution:

NOTE: For access to network drives off-campus, usage of the GlobalProtect VPN is required. Additional solutions exist on how to install and use GlobalProtect.

Press the Start button, type This PC and press the Enter key. In the window that opens, open the Computer tab at the top and click on the Map Network Drive button. There are multiple different drives that MSOE provides, and mapping them each involve a slightly different process. All users have access to the O: and M: drives, but only staff and faculty have access to the H: drive.

For the Department O: Drive:
For Drive, select the O: option. For Folder, type in \\filestore.ad.msoe.edu\Department. Ensure that Reconnect at Sign-In is selected. If the drive is being mapped on an MSOE laptop, then Connect Using Different Credentials can remain unselected; if the drive is being mapped on a non-MSOE laptop, then it needs to be selected. Click the Finish button. If the drive is being mappen on a non-MSOE laptop, then when prompted log in with AD\[MSOE username] and the password associated with that account.

For the MSOE M: Drive:
For Drive, select the M: option. For Folder, type in \\filestore.ad.msoe.edu\MSOE. Ensure that Reconnect at Sign-In is selected. If the drive is being mapped on an MSOE laptop, then Connect Using Different Credentials can remain unselected; if the drive is being mapped on a non-MSOE laptop, then it needs to be selected. Click the Finish button. If the drive is being mappen on a non-MSOE laptop, then when prompted log in with AD\[MSOE username] and the password associated with that account.

For the Home H: Drive: (Not currently supported, all that have it are the last to have it)
For Drive, select the H: option. For Folder, type in \\homestore.ad.msoe.edu\homedrives$\[MSOE username]. Ensure that Reconnect at Sign-In is selected. If the drive is being mapped on an MSOE laptop, then Connect Using Different Credentials can remain unselected; if the drive is being mapped on a non-MSOE laptop, then it needs to be selected. Click the Finish button. If the drive is being mappen on a non-MSOE laptop, then when prompted log in with AD\[MSOE username] and the password associated with that account.


Updated: 2/21/2018

solution-article.title: Recovering Missing or Deleted Files on a Network Drive
solution-article.description:
Title:

Recovering Missing or Deleted Files on a Network Drive


Summary:

The MSOE M: and O: drives support a feature called shadow volume copy. This feature grants any user connected to the network drive the ability to recover any deleted files within a short time period of its deletion.


Solution:

Navigate to the folder where the file originally was. Right click on empty space in the folder and click on the Properties button. In the window that opens, open the Previous Versions tab.

In this tab will be displayed any backups available. Select one of the backup times and press the Open button. DO NOT press the Restore button; this overwrites all current files in the directory with old versions. After pressing the Open button, a window will open displaying all files in the backup. Select individual files to copy over to the laptop or network drive.

The H: drive does not support shadow volume copy. Instead, any files deleted off of this drive will be moved to a Recycle Bin folder in the top level of the drive directory. The files will remain for three days before being permanently deleted.


Updated: 2/21/2018

solution-article.title: Mounting Network Drive on a Mac
solution-article.description:
First make sure you are connected to the "MSOE" wifi network or hardwired in and not "MSOE-Guest." You can also be connected to the MSOE VPN.

--------------- For O: Drive ----------------------------------------------------

1). Hit "command K" on the keyboard or select 'connect to server' in the Go menu
2). Type 'smb://filestore.ad.msoe.edu/department' as the server name
3). You will be prompted for login credentials please use 'AD\username' as your username and your normal email password.
4). Check 'remember password in my key chain' if you want to remember the connection after logout.
5). click connect
---------------- For M: Drive ----------------------------------------------------

1). Hit "command K" on the keyboard or select 'connect to server' in the Go menu
2). Type 'smb://filestore.ad.msoe.edu/MSOE' as the server name
3). You will be prompted for login credentials please use 'AD\username' as your username and your normal email password.
4). Check 'remember password in my key chain' if you want to remember the connection after logout.
5). click connect
---------------- For H: Drive --------------------------------------------------------

1). Hit "command K" on the keyboard or select 'connect to server' in the Go menu
2). Type 'smb://filestore.ad.msoe.edu/homedrives$/username' as the server name
3). You will be prompted for login credentials please use 'AD\username' as your username and your normal email password.
4). Check 'remember password in my key chain' if you want to remember the connection after logout.
5). click connect
Please note that this H: drive solution is untested

solution-article.title: Mounting Network Drives on Linux
solution-article.description:
Make sure you are connected to the MSOE wifi or VPN (not MSOE-Guest) or are hardwired in on campus.

Mounting Network Drives in Linux

First install the “samba” package. Run the following commands in the terminal for your distribution.

Ubuntu/Debian based:

sudo apt install samba


RHEL/Fedora based

sudo dnf install samba


Arch Linux based:

sudo pacman -S samba


Solus Linux:

sudo eopkg install samba



Open a GUI file manager:

While the exact instructions will vary depending on the file manager you are using, on Dolphin (file manager for the KDE Plasma desktop) the instructions are as follows (will be very similar for most others):


There should be a tab in the “Places” section called “Network.” Click on it and you should see an option for “Samba shares” or “Windows shares” or something similar. Click on it and enter one of the following depending on the drive you want to mount (the "smb:" might be auto filled in):


“smb://filestore.ad.msoe.edu/department” For the O: Drive


“smb://filestore.ad.msoe.edu/MSOE” For the M: Drive


“smb://filestore.ad.msoe.edu/homedrives$/username” For the H: Drive


You will be asked for login credentials. Enter AD\username (replacing username with your MSOE username) and use your MSOE password. The drive should be mounted now.

solution-folder.name: Other
solution-folder.description: This folder contains materials that pertain to procedures that do not fall under any other folders that are public to customers.

solution-article.title: XBox One - Cannot Get a Teredo IP Address and Strict NAT Type Issues
solution-article.description:
Title:

XBox One - Cannot Get a Teredo IP Address and Strict NAT Type Issues


Summary:

In the MSOE dorms, a couple of common issues that show up with consoles are an inability to obtain a Teredo IP address and issues with hosting games due to a Strict NAT type.


Solution:

Teredo is an IPv4 to IPv6 conversion protocol. However, our network, while capable of IPv6, does not currently route IPv6 traffic. This would require setting up all new DHCP subnets, and rewriting each firewall rule for both IPv4 and IPv6 objects. However, IPv6 by design will always fail back to IPv4 when it cannot establish a connection. While Xbox One users will not be able to get rid of the error message "Cannot Get a Teredo IP Address", they should still be able to use their XBox One and XBox Live normally, and join/chat in multiplayers games.


Some things to can try to correct a "Strict NAT" issue:

Add the XBox One to the DMZ on their router, if they have one that allows DMZ addresses

Enable UPNP to allow necessary ports to be available to the XBox One (may require router and XBox One reboot)


Open the following ports (either do this or enable UPNP, not both):

Port 88 (UDP)

Port 3074 (UDP and TCP)

Port 53 (UDP and TCP)

Port 80 (TCP)

Port 500 (UDP)

UDP Port 3544 (UDP)

UDP Port 4500 (UDP)

Reset the MAC address of the XBO: Settings > network > Advanced settings > Alternate mac address > Clear


MSOE does not use NAT at this time. All IP addresses are internet-routable, and are not translated IP addresses. The IP obtained when connecting to our network is the one that people outside our network see. A NAT will only occur if the XBox One is connected using a router or switch that provides DHCP other than the DHCP provided by MSOE. 


[UPDATE 8/22/2018] All buildings now use NAT, and outbound IP addresses are given a Class-B Public address when they leave the firewall. Double-NATting may be an issue when using your own router.


That being said, we are familiar with what XBox One considers NAT. Errors along the line of "Can't get a Teredo IP address" may appear indicating that XBox One did not get and cannot see an IPv6 network. MSOE blocks all IPv6 traffic as our servers, routers, and firewalls do not have policies in place to manage IPv6 traffic. All IPv6 traffic will revert to IPv4 if it cannot establish a connection. Use of IPv6 or IPv4 will not impact network experience.


There are some steps to take if a router or switch is between the device and our network. Ports on the router can be forwarded to the IP address of the XBox One. This will require giving the XBox One a static IP address.


The XBox One can also be placed in the DMZ of the route. This will also require a static IP, but is less effort than setting up port forwarding. This puts the XBox One outside of the security provided by the router. 


MSOE provides internet to students as best we can, while not sacrificing the safety or experience of other users. An Open NAT may not be granted while on our network for the reasons above, as well as others. This should not impact the speed and quality of the gaming experience, but it may prevent hosting in some games.


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_address_translation

http://support.xbox.com/en-US/xbox-one/networking/network-ports-used-xbox-live

Updated: 2/21/18

solution-article.title: Accessing GET Funds Through a Web Browser and on Mobile Devices
solution-article.description:
Accessing GET Funds in a Web Browser


  • Navigate to get.cbord.com/msoe
  • Click Sign up now! Under the password box
  • Fill out your information, using your MSOE email and ID number but setting a new password



  • Click Register and get back to the login screen
  • Log in using your MSOE email and newly created password


  • On the main screen you can:
See Account Overview
Shows how much money is left on the Raider Plan, how many Meal Dollars are left for the semester, as well as how many Meal Swipes are left if not enrolled in the Platinum meal plan.

See Recent Transactions
On this screen the last four charges to the account are displayed, whether it is from the Raider Plan, Meal Dollars, or Meal Swipes. A more detailed Transaction History can be accessed by clicking View All Transaction History.

There are also a few quick links provided, as well as a way to email friends and family requesting funds.


Accessing GET Funds on Mobile Devices

  • Open the Play Store on Android devices or the iOS App Store on Apple devices
  • Search for Get Mobile and install the application by The CBORD Group


  • Once installed, open it and go to Select Institution where you scroll down to select Milwaukee School of Engineering
  • On the login screen select Register
  • Fill out your information, using your MSOE email and ID number but setting a new password


  • Click Register and get back to the login screen
  • Log in using your MSOE email and newly created password


  • On the next screen set a new four-digit pin


  • From here you can:
View your accounts
See how much is left on the Raider Plan, how many Meal Dollars are left for the semester, as well as how many Meal Swipes are left if not enrolled in the Platinum meal plan.

Add funds
Add funds to the Raider Plan using a credit card.

View your transaction history
See any charges to the Raider Plan, Meal Dollars used, or Meal Swipes used.

See Recent Transactions On this screen the last four charges to the account are displayed, whether it is from the Raider Plan, Meal Dollars, or Meal Swipes. A more detailed Transaction History can be accessed by clicking View All Transaction History.

solution-article.title: Registering and Changing MSOE Account Passwords
solution-article.description:
Title:

Registering and Changing MSOE Account Passwords


Summary:

With the addition of a new domain, the ability to change MSOE passwords by pressing the CTRL + ALT + DEL keys has been disabled to prevent communication issues. We have set up website portals to provide this functionality instead.


Solution:

To use the password reset portal, the account needs to be registered at the Password Registration Portal. This portal is at https://pwdreg.msoe.edu/. A current valid password is required to register an account. Log in to the registration portal, and fill in at least three security questions to register the account.

After registering, the account password can be unlocked or changed at the Password Reset Portal. This portal is at https://pwd.msoe.edu/. This portal can be used with an expired password, as all that is required is the account username and the security questions.

When changing passwords, the requirements for a valid password are that the password needs a minimum of 12 characters, and the password cannot be identical to any of the four previous passwords that have been used.

If an account is expired and has not been registered at the Password Registration Portal, then the account owner will need to come to the MSOE IT Helpdesk in person, bringing along identification, in order to have the account password reset to the default. Following FERPA regulations, this cannot be done over phone or email, and must be in person.


Updated: 4/25/2018

solution-article.title: Resetting Alumni Email Account Passwords
solution-article.description:
Title:
Resetting Alumni Email Account Passwords

Summary:

Alumni email accounts are handled through Gmail, making their passwords unable to be reset through the normal MSOE account password reset method.


Solution:

Head to https://gapps.msoe.edu//alumni/password/index.php. Fill out the form in order to have the account password reset. The form must be filled out with exactly the same information that the account was registered with.

solution-article.title: Directly Calling an MSOE Voicemail
solution-article.description:
Title:
Directly Calling an MSOE Voicemail

Summary:

MSOE voicemail accounts are able to be directly called from an MSOE phone in order to bypass waiting for the phone to ring.


Solution:

Press the star (*) button before entering the extension in order to directly call that extension's voicemail.


Updated: 2/21/2018

solution-article.title: Resetting Voicemail Passwords
solution-article.description:
Title:
Resetting Voicemail Passwords

Summary:

While voicemail passwords do not expire, they can still be changed in the case that the password is forgotten.


Solution:

NOTE: The voicemail password will only be able to be changed by the person whose account the voicemail is associated with, as it requires logging in with that person's MSOE account.

Head to the ciscovoicemail.msoe.edu website. This will open a page telling you that the website does not have a secure connection. This is normal. If this is being done in Google Chrome, click on Advanced at the bottom of the page, and click on Proceed to ucon01.msoe.edu (unsafe). If this is being done in Mozilla Firefox, Click on the Advanced button at the bottom of the page, in the window that opens click on the Add Exception... button, and then in the next window that opens click on the Confirm Security Exception button.

Log in to the website with the MSOE credentials that are associated with the account. Click on Managing Assistant. Click on the Password dropdown menu and choose Change Pin. The password can now be set. It can only include numbers, and requires at least six characters. Click on the Save button when finished.

This method can only be used to change the account's voicemail password once every 24 hours.


Updated: 2/21/2018
